results.title: L'incoronazione di Poppea
results.creator_credit: Robin Lough, BBC-TV, Glyndebourne Productions and Peter Hall
results.brief_description: A dramatic opera of passion and betrayal, “L’Incoronazione di Poppea” by Claudio Monteverdi, libretto by Francesco Busenello, tells the amoral story of the Roman Emperor Nero’s love affair with the scheming and seductive Poppea. Maria Ewing plays the manipulative and evil Poppea and Dennis Bailey is Nerone, her Emperor lover, with a supporting cast including Cynthia Clarey, Robert Lloyd, Elizabeth Gale, Dale Duesing. Features the Glyndebourne Chorus and the London Philharmonic Orchestra conducted by Raymond Leppard who is also responsible for making this modern edition of the opera. Includes an introduction by Peter Hall and a translated printed program in English and Italian. Sung in Italian. Recorded for television as part of the Glyndebourne Festival series.

results.title: L'immortelle = the Immortal Woman
results.creator_credit: Dino De Laurentiis and Alain Robbe-Grillet
results.brief_description:
Andre and Leilah meet and become lovers. After a bizarre car accident, Leilah dies. Andre sets out to investigate Leilah’s death. Awards: Prix Louis-Delluc 1963.

Credits: Producer: Dino De Laurentiis ; director, Alain Robbe-Grillet ; writer, Alain Robbe-Grillet ; photography, Maurice Barry ; music, Georges Delerue.
Cast: Jacques Doniol-Valcroze, Francoise Brion.

results.title: L'Ile de la Cite
results.creator_credit: John Seabourne and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description: An American girl visits the Ile de la Cite, the quais de la Seine and Ile Saint-Louis and has tea with a French friend. Conversation with a quayside bookseller, explanations of the island’s monuments and buildings and a humorous incident involving a phone call are also included. In French langauge.

results.title: L'idiot = the Idiot
results.brief_description:
Russian prince Muichkine returns to St. Petersburg after a stay in a Swiss mental hospital. Blissfully unaware of the greater social problems of his country, the prince believes that love and goodness reign supreme around him. He becomes betrothed to an innocent young girl while trying to save a less-innocent woman from her downfall. Jealousy and his own naivete conjoin to bring about an unimaginable tragedy. ‘L’idiot’ was remade in Japan by Akira Kurosawa (1951) and in Russia by Ivan Pyriev (1958).

Credits: Producer, Sacha Gordine ; director, Georges Lampin ; writers, Charles Spaak, Georges Raewsky ; photography, Christian Matras ; music, Maurice Thiriet, V. de Butzow.
Cast: Gerard Philipe, Edwige Feuillere, Lucien Coedel, Nathalie Nattier, Marguerite Moreno, Jean Debucourt, Sylvie.

results.title: L'horloger de Saint Paul = the Clockmaker of Saint Paul
results.brief_description:
For his first feature film, Bertrand Tavernier chose to transport the Simenon characters to his native town of Lyons. Michel Descombes works as a clockmaker in the St-Paul area of Lyons. One evening he finds the Police at his door asking about his son, Bernard. Bernard is suspected of shooting a security guard at a factory and has run away with his girlfriend. As the Police enquiry progresses, Michel realises he knows very little about his son and can hardly assist Commissioner Guiboud. The choice of Aurenche and Bost as screenwriters can be regarded as an anti ‘Nouvelle Vague’ statement from Tavernier. Both writers were strongly associated with film-makers such as Claude Autant-Lara and a more traditional style of cinema. Awards: Prix Louis Delluc 1973 ; Berlin Film Festival 1974 - Special Jury Prize.

Credits: Producer, Raymond Danon ; director, Bertrand Tavernier ; writers, Jean Aurenche, Pierre Bost, Bertrand Tavernier ; photography, Pierre-William Glenn ; music, Philippe Sarde.
Cast: Philippe Noiret, Jean Rochefort, Jacques Denis, Clotilde Joanno, Sylvain Rougerie, Christine Pascal, Monique Chaumette, William Sabatier.

results.title: L'homme Qui Ment = the Man Who Lies
results.creator_credit: Samy Halfon, Maurice Urbain and Alain Robbe-Grillet
results.brief_description:
Boris Varissa arrives in a small Central European village, used as a haven by local Resitance fighters. He sweet talks his way into the good graces of a family in mourning after the deeath of their son Jean, a Resistance fighter. This avant garde feature leaves the viewer to decide if Boris is telling the truth or covering up for his deeds leading to the death of the heroic Resistance fighter. Awards: Berlin International Film Festival (1968): Best Male Performance for Jean-Louis Trintignant.

Credits: Producers, Maurice Urbain, Samy Halfon ; director, Alain Robbe-Grillet ; writer, Alain Robbe-Grillet ; photography, Igor Luther ; music, Michel Fano ; editor, Bob Wade.
Cast: Jean-Louis Trintignant, Sylvie Breal, Dominique Prado, Ivan Mistrik, Sylvia Turbova, Catherine Robbe-Grillet, Zuzana Kocurikova, Jozef Kroner, Julius Vasek.

results.title: L'homme de Neandertal
results.brief_description:
Episode 2 of Series “Il Etait Une Fois L’homme” (= “Once Upon a Time Man”).This episode takes us among a tribe of hunters and gatherers to find out more about their tool making techniques. We also discover how their society is affected by the Ice Age.

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Barille ; photography, Jean-Louis Karcher ; art direction, Philippe Landrot, Rene Borg ; graphic research, Jean Barbaud.
Cast: Roger Carel, Francine Laine, Pierre Trabaud, Henri Djanik [original French narration].

results.title: L'homme Au Chapeau Rond
results.brief_description:
When his wife Nathalie dies, Nicolas, a former judge, hits the bottle. His mood becomes even grimmer when he learns that his daughter Lisa is in fact the result of Nathalie’s affair with Michel. One night, Nicolas approaches Michel with his revelations and Michel promises to look after the child. But soon after the child is despatched to the country and the two men resume their favorite game: womanising.

Credits: Director, Pierre Billon ; writers, Charles Spaak, Pierre Brive ; photography, Nicolas Toporkoff ; music, Maurice Thiriet ; art direction, Georges Wakhevitch.
Cast: Raimu, Aime Clariond, Lucy Valnor, Gisele Casadessus, Louis Seigner, Jane Marken, Micheline Boudet, France Delahalle.

results.title: L'homme a la Pipe = Man with the Pipe
results.brief_description:
Documentary on 19th century French painter, Gustave Courbet.

Credits: Director, Roger Leenhardt ; photography, Georges Lendi ; music, Jean Wiener.

results.title: L'heritier = the Heir
results.brief_description:
Bart Cordell inherits his father’s business following his father’s accidental death. Bart is convinced the circumstances of this death were dubious and may be part of a ploy to destabilise his financial empire. He hires a private detective and finds that a reporter working for his father’s magazine (one of the many companies he owned) was looking into plans by another multinational to take over the company. Cordell also discovers that his father-in-law, a former Italian fascist, may not have given up his old loyalties.

Credits: Producer, Jacques-Eric Strauss ; director, Philippe Labro ; writers, Jacques Lanzmann, Philippe Labro ; photography, Jean Penzer ; music, Michel Colombier ; art direction, Theobald Meurisse.
Cast: Jean-Paul Belmondo, Carla Gravina, Jean Rochefort, Charles Denner, Maureen Kerwin.
